data.title: [PDF] IUE Spring 2025 Research Symposium - UW-Milwaukee
data.snippet:
Conclusions “When your (ways of) being and knowing are constantly delegitimized, disrespected, marginalized, inferiorized, attacked, erased, and/or destroyed, how do you continue to be?” — Jeong-eun Rhee & Binaya Subedi, 2014, p. 340 For many students in America’s inner-city public schools, this question is not hypothetical—it is a lived reality. The erasure of Black and Hispanic/(Afro-)Latin students’ cultural identities, histories, and ways of knowing has been embedded within the education system, creating barriers to engagement, achievement, and self-perception. The Eurocentric foundation of science curricula further amplifies this exclusion, sending implicit and explicit messages that certain forms of knowledge, storytelling, and inquiry are more legitimate than others. This course [...] Rhee, J. E., & Subedi, B. (2014). Colonizing and decolonizing projects of re/covering spirituality. Educational Studies, 50(4), 339-356.
Smith, L. T. (2013). Decolonizing methodologies: Research and indigenous peoples. Zed Books Ltd.
Purpose This study examines best practices in youth engagement and youth-adult partnerships by integrating a literature search with real-world case studies. By analyzing both theoretical frameworks and lived experiences, it offers actionable insights for strengthening authentic youth-adult collaboration.
